In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here is the solution in Julia:

```julia
function wrap_string(s::String, text_width::Int = 10)
    words = split(s, " ")
    result = ""
    current_line_length = 0
    for word in words
        if length(word) + current_line_length > text_width
            result *= "\n"
            current_line_length = 0
        end
        result *= " $word"
        current_line_length += length(word) + 1
    end
    return result
end
```
This function splits the input string into words, then iterates over each word. If adding a new word would exceed `text_width`, it starts a new line. It also adds a space before each word to keep the words separate. The resulting string is returned.

Here's an example usage:
```julia
print(wrap_string("Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit"))
```
This will print:
```
Lorem ipsum 
dolor sit amet, 
consectetur 
adipiscing elit
```
